There have been multiple requests that revolve around screenshot / recording detection and/or blocking, and while they are all slightly different, they have a significant amount of overlap and result in duplicate discussions.

Due to the timespan of the threads and related discussion, rather than a confusing merge of all the posts, I am simply going to close the other topics and link them here.

Any discussion relating to screenshot / recording detection and/or blocking can be continued in this topic.

(Inspired by Improved profile sharing controls.)

Additionally, please note that the Signal team has replied the following to one of the requests:

Seeing that the other party has taken a screenshot Feature Requests
There are children’s toys that trivially bypass useless techniques like screenshot detection. Even if your conversation partner doesn’t have access to cutting-edge playground technology, all bets are off if you send a photo to someone who secretly possesses a photographic memory :) This is meant to be a fun feature that can help keep your conversation history tidy and save space for the photographs and videos that matter.

Because that appears to imply that such features won’t be implemented, this topic is in General Discussion rather than Feature Requests.

posts.cooked:
True!
For long term archival also essential.

I really hope not. In what aspect is this feature considered “good”? Why should Signal waste time on such a stupid feature that is only there to create the illusion of security. These are strategies the “bad” messengers use to lure in people that want to be secure but don’t understand the technicalities. It’s nothing Signal should even touch.

And no, the screen security option in Signal Android is for security on your own phone and prevents malicious Apps from spying on your messages by grabbing the screen.

And yes, circumventing any kind of screenshot protection is as easy as opening your desktop App and pressing PrntScrn.

And no, Signal should not do stupid things like making sensitive messages appear on mobile only, because all Signal instances are explicitly independent of each other and are also meant to be used independently. That means, if someone chooses to use Desktop only because whatever, they wouldn’t be able to receive certain messages which would be very bad UX. Or even worse, they wouldn’t be able to receive any messages from certain users with this option turned on.

So to everyone that wants this feature implemented: Please inform yourself about the impossibility of creating a working version of this “feature”. It only creates a false sense of security which is worse than not having this feature all together.

posts.cooked: Currently there is no point of it because we can screenshot it. However, Signal has already a secure mode that doesn’t let other apps and Android look on Signal’s inner content (mesaages, the UI). We could achive blocking screenshots if Signal enabled that “secure” mode when viewing those once appearing media files. By the secure mode I mean flag=secure

d4f5409d:

Signal has already a secure mode that doesn’t let other apps and Android look on Signal’s inner content

No it doesn’t.
It does not allow to do so on your phone, but you don’t/can’t know if other phones actually pay attention to Signal politely asking the OS to not allow screen capture.
The implementation relies on the Android OS to do as it’s told and it’s not that difficult to do one of the following:

  • Change the Signal Android client to omit the requests of not allowing screenshots
  • Change the Android OS your phone is running so that it ignores screenshot blocking/detection

This feature is only intended to be used with people you trust, but Signal can’t guarantee that the other person hasn’t stored the picture on their device.
Implementing this feature would only be security theater

link_counts.title: Why does Signal implement seemingly unimportant configuration options?

posts.cooked:
The thing is…
When you change an app icon you can see for yourself what are the effects of that given action (i.e. the icon of Signal is now changed ).
However, no such proof is available when we talk about features that cannot be enforced on technical (e.g. custom clients) or “environmental” (e.g. CCTV) levels. (Features like remote deletion, screenshot prevention, etc.)

On top of that, actions like changing app icons, hiding apps, PIN protecting them and so on, should be considered a part of physical/personal security and are meant to obstruct actions of someone in “momentary possession” of your unlocked device. Actions such as checking if you have app X installed on your phone. It takes 5 seconds to check for Signal icon on the grid, but it’d take much longer to open each and every app one by one, because Signal might be masquerading as one of them.

Not to say that I’m a fan of the icon changing feature in its current form, but screenshot “prevention” is a peak security bulls#!t. And anecdotally, speaking from experience: no, people do not consider that their interlocutor could use a second device to preserve their “view-once” media. Let alone custom clients…

And all of this that I’ve just written is absolutely in line with Signal’s current position on disappearing messages (emphasis mine):

Use disappearing messages to keep your message history tidy. The message will disappear from your devices after the timer has elapsed. This is not for situations where your contact is your adversary — after all, if someone who receives a disappearing message really wants a record of it, they can always use another camera to take a photo of the screen before the message disappears.
